title: R Users & R-Ladies Warsaw (Spotkania Entuzjastów R): Preserving wildlife with computer vision + Scaling Shiny Dashboards on a Budget  [Virtual] , Poland, Europe
group: R Users & R-Ladies Warsaw (Spotkania Entuzjastów R)
description:
# Stream url
- https://youtu.be/c1o4LHO5hQ4

# Talks
- company - Appsilon https://appsilon.com/
- Preserving wildlife with computer vision - Jędrzej Świeżewski PhD https://www.linkedin.com/in/swiezew/
- Scaling Shiny Dashboards on a Budget - Damian Budelewski https://www.linkedin.com/in/damianbudelewski

# Current Open Positions at Appsilon
Project Manager
https://appsilon.com/careers/#project-manager
Community Manager
https://appsilon.com/careers/#community-manager
Frontend Engineer
https://appsilon.com/careers/#frontend-engineer
Infrastructure engineer
https://appsilon.com/careers/#senior-infrastructure-engineer
R Shiny developer
https://appsilon.com/careers/#r-shiny-developer

# Details
- webinars http://whyr.pl/webinars/
- donate http://whyr.pl/donate/
- join Why R? Slack http://whyr.pl/slack/
- join Meetup http://tiny.cc/WarsawRUG
- format: 45 min talk + 15 min for Q&A
- comments: ask YouTube live chat

# Speakers

### Jędrzej Świeżewski PhD
Jędrzej's current main focus is exploring both the applications of computer vision and the boundaries of the applicability of the tools involved. His background is in theoretical physics.
In his free time Jędrzej enjoys skiing and ice skating.

### Damian Budelewski
Damian has a Bachelor's Degree in Electronics and Communication and works as Infrastructure Engineer at Appsilon. He is interested in Cloud services, DevOps methodology, and cybersecurity.

# Descriptions of talk

### Preserving wildlife with computer vision
In this talk, I will discuss how we have managed to assist wildlife conservationists in their efforts in central Africa, using computer vision. I will touch on the modelling, the real life implementation and also share a treat for R lovers.

### Scaling Shiny Dashboards on a Budget
I will discuss being prepared for a high traffic load, and understanding the costs and requirements of hosting shiny apps on the cloud. All of this on the example of a shiny app deployed on Shiny Server Open Source and hosted on AWS.

# Sponsors

The event will be sponsored by Appsilon.

Appsilon delivers the most advanced R Shiny apps, data science consulting services and support with R Shiny and Python Dash technologies.
www: https://appsilon.com
fb: https://fb.com/appsilondatascience
twitter: https://twitter.com/appsilonds
linkedin: https://linkedin.com/company/appsilon/

title: R Users & R-Ladies Warsaw (Spotkania Entuzjastów R): Why R? Webinar 023 - Ewa Grabska - Satellite imagery analysis in R  [Virtual] , Poland, Europe
group: R Users & R-Ladies Warsaw (Spotkania Entuzjastów R)
description:
- stream https://youtu.be/k1K6nqgtRL8

- speaker Ewa Grabska https://www.linkedin.com/in/ewa-grabska-731b30100
- webinars http://whyr.pl/webinars/
- donate http://whyr.pl/donate/
- join Why R? Slack http://whyr.pl/slack/
- format: 45 min talk + 15 min for Q&A
- comments: ask YouTube live chat

Description:
Satellite imagery, such as freely available data from Sentinel-2 mission, enable us to monitor the Earth's surface frequently (every 5 days), and with a high spatial resolution (10-20 meters). Furthermore, Sentinel-2 sensors, including 13 spectral bands in the visible and infrared wavelengths, provide very valuable information which can be used to automatically perform tasks such as classify crop types, assess forest changes, or monitor build-up area development. This is particularly important now, in the era of rapid changes in the environment related to climate change. In R, there are plenty of tools and packages which can be used for satellite images such as pre-processing, analyzing, and visualizing data in a simple and efficient way. Also, the variety of methods, such as machine learning algorithms, are available in R and can be applied in the analysis of satellite imagery. I would like to show the framework for acquiring, pre-processing and preliminary analysis of the Sentinel-2 time series in R. It includes the spectral indices calculation, the use of the machine learning algorithms in the classification of land cover, and, the analysis of time series of imagery, i.e. determining the changes in environment based on the spectral trajectories of pixels.

Biography:
Ewa is a Ph.D. candidate in geography at the Jagiellonian University, and a research assistant at the Faculty of Forestry, the University of Agriculture in Kraków. In her research, she focus on the use of Sentinel-2 satellite imagery in determining different forest characteristics, such as tree species composition or detection of forest disturbances. She is also a big R enthusiast and she mostly use it in my analysis!

title: R Users & R-Ladies Warsaw (Spotkania Entuzjastów R): X-Europe Webinar #11 - Get Started with ML in Azure Quantum Computing with Q#  [Virtual] , Poland, Europe
group: R Users & R-Ladies Warsaw (Spotkania Entuzjastów R)
description:
############### Register

https://quantum-ml.carrd.co/

############### Speaker

Pamela Krzypkowska. Part of Microsoft technical team. Previously, worked mainly as a developer in the areas of internet of things, natural language processing, and in the areas of analytics and automation. A graduate of Computer Science at the Warsaw University of Technology and a student of Philosophy at the University of Warsaw. Her more-or-less professional interests include: artificial intelligence, cognitive science and philosophy of mind.

LinkedIn https://www.linkedin.com/in/pamela-krzypkowska/

############### Description

The purpose of the session is to showcase Microsoft Quantum Development Kit and to demonstrate how Quantum Computing tools can be used for building Machine Learning algorithms with Azure Quantum. During the talk, I will show you how to use QDK (Quantum Development Kit) to create a model for the classification of a standard dataset in Q#. At last I will present the differences in the standard approach to ML and describe the profit from the use of quantum data processing tools.

################## ABOUT THE X-EUROPE DATA SCIENCE WEBINARS

This is a joint online event of Vienna Data Science Group, Frankfurt Data Science, Budapest Data Science Meetup, BCN Analytics, Budapest.AI, Barcelona Data Science and Machine Learning Meetup, Budapest Deep Learning Reading Seminar and Warsaw R Users Group.

title: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language): 300 lessons later: What I've learned about R from teaching R  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language)
description:
300 lessons later: What I've learned about R from teaching R
Presented by Mark Niemann-Ross

Robert Heinlein said "When one teaches, two learn" - and I'm proof! I started learning R in 2014, taught my first R course in 2015. I started with a casual knowledge of data science, statistics, and matrix math.

Since then, have taught more than 300 sessions to nearly 60,000 learners. I've covered matrices, NLP, linear models, program flow and other details of the R language.

But enough about me - how about you? Let's discuss the objections I've heard about passing on your knowledge to the next generation. I'll cover the imposter syndrome, lack of venue, and "I'm a researcher, not an educator."

In ten minutes, you'll have your confidence restored and your awesomeness confirmed.

Mark Niemann-Ross is an author & educator. He teaches for LinkedIn Learning, focused on the R programming language and Raspberry Pi. He is the author of "Stupid Machine" - a science fiction murder mystery solved by a refrigerator.

title: Salt Lake City R Users Group: Combining R & Python with reticulate   [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Salt Lake City R Users Group
description:
Our November Meetup will be a remote gathering; the Zoom link will be posted the week of the event.

How do we choose between using R & Python? R is a familiar language that is powerful in statistical analysis and provides us with great graphics and visualization tools. Python is great for its readability and excels in machine learning models and mathematical computations. Using reticulate, we can leverage the power of both languages in a single environment. In this talk we will show how to use reticulate to model the COVID-19 pandemic.

Gabriella Smith is a data scientist at Intermountain Healthcare. She has a background in applied mathematics and statistics. Her interests include modeling and creating interactive tools.

title: Salt Lake City R Users Group: Looking at stop words: why you shouldn't blindly trust model defaults  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Salt Lake City R Users Group
description:
Our December Meetup will be a remote gathering; it is our September meeting (which was canceled due to the wind storm and power outages) but rescheduled! The Zoom link will be posted the week of the event.

Removing stop words is a fairly common step in natural language processing, and NLP packages often supply a default list. However, most documentation and tutorials don't explore the nuances of selecting an appropriate list. Defaults for machine learning and modeling can be helpful but may be misleading or wrong. This talk will focus on the importance of checking assumptions and defaults in the software you use.

Emil Hvitfeldt is a research programmer at University of Southern California, a co-organizer of East Los Angeles R Users Group, and the author of [Supervised Machine Learning for Text Analysis in R](https://smltar.com/) with his coauthor Julia Silge. His interests include developing tools for natural language processing for machine learning models and the use of colors in data visualizations.

title: Portland R User Group: aggregate: meet, greet, learn, collaborate  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Please join us for the 36th R aggRegate meetup on Zoom! We welcome current or aspiring R users who have any level of experience with the R programming language.

Our goal is to exchange knowledge, learn new skills, help each other troubleshoot coding problems, and meet new fellow R users.

No topic is off limits, and you may attend even if you don’t feel that you have anything to share. Come learn with us!

Details: RStudio Connect is a standalone publishing platform for the work your teams create in R and Python. Give your data scientists one convenient place to share Shiny applications, R Markdown reports, dashboards, plots, models, APIs, Jupyter Notebooks, interactive Python content, and more.

RStudio Connect isn’t just for data scientists. Now anyone can interact with custom-built data products developed by R and Python users: Dashboards, reports, notebooks, presentations, documents, even interactive web applications, without having to program in R or Python themselves.

Join Kelly O'Briant (RStudio) as she does a short demonstration of RStudio Connect as a platform. A Q&A session will follow

When: November 17th, 2020 @ 6:30-8 PM

Where: Online: zoom info provided when you respond

Agenda:

• Kelly O'Briant (RStudio) will do a short demonstration of RStudio Connect as a platform

• Brief intro/R project or problem: We'll take turns talking about an R project we're working on, a data/data-science problem, or something we want to learn, etc.

• Next, anyone can share some code they've been working on and want help with / want feedback on. Make sure to have this ready before the meeting.

• Before arriving, use the pdxrlang/aggregate GitHub repository to discuss ideas for things to work on at aggregate - https://github.com/pdxrlang/aggregate/issues

Please note that this event, like all PDX R events, adheres to the PDX R Code of Conduct: https://pdxrlang.com/code_of_conduct We are dedicated to a safe learning environment to all.

If you have any trouble message Marley Buchman in the meetup app, or on Twitter at @pdxrlang

title: Auckland R Users Group (AKLRUG): Reproducible Science at Dragonfly, New Zealand, Australia
description:
After a long break, we can finally announce a new R Meetup and an exciting talk about reproducible Data Science!

Abstract:
Caleb Moses is a data scientist for Dragonfly Data Science, a data science consulting company based in Wellington which does work on everything from environmental science and ecology to Māori language. Dragonfly is passionate about using automation to make their work as reproducible as possible. Caleb will talk about the techniques he uses to automate his work and build pipelines that run from the raw data right through to a final report or a website.

Short Bio:
Caleb has been working at Dragonfly as a Data Scientist for over 2 years. His work is on applying machine learning to Māori language by training speech processing pipelines using machine learning. Before Dragonfly he worked at Stats NZ, where he was a subject matter expert in statistical confidentiality for integrated data. Nowadays, he is outspoken on the societal implications of the use of data and algorithms in the modern age.

title: R-Ladies Bari: Dati personali e informazioni sensibili: tecniche di data anonymization in R  [Virtual] , Italy, Europe
description:
📣 Evento in collaborazione con la community del Deep Learning Italia

"Deep Learning Italia” Online Conference: https://bit.ly/3m50KSL

Si affronteranno temi legati esclusivamente alla progettazione e implementazione di Reti Neurali e il Deep Learning nell'Intelligenza Artificiale di oggi.

Il Meetup di DLI nasce dall'esigenza di sopperire alla carenza di meetup tecnici sul Deep Learning in Italia mentre ormai se ne contano molteplici in altre città del mondo come Londra, Amsterdam e San Francisco. Il Meetup sarà orientato sia alla ricerca accademica e che al mondo delle startup.

Lunedì 23 Novembre 2020, dalle ore 18.30 alle ore 20.00.

REGISTRAZIONE OBBLIGATORIA SU CODEMOTION: https://community.codemotion.com/deep-learning-italia/meetups/meetup-aperitech-online-edition-di-novembre-di-deep-learning-italia

Speaker:
Giovanna de Vincenzo Co-Founder @R-Ladies Bari | Data Scientist @InfoCamere

Titolo: Dati personali e informazioni sensibili: tecniche di data anonymization in R

Abstract

Con i social media e i big data ovunque, la privacy dei dati è diventata una preoccupazione pubblica crescente. La raccolta di informazioni è necessaria per aiutare un sito web a crescere, targetizzare i clienti o analizzare fenomeni sociali. Riconoscendo questo problema, tante entità come Google e Apple, stanno promuovendo migliori tecniche di tutela e protezione della privacy. È qui che entra in gioco l'anonimizzazione dei dati.

📣 Cos'è l'anonimizzazione dei dati e perché è importante?

L'anonimizzazione dei dati rende non identificabili le informazioni identificabili. Ciò avviene tramite tecniche di elaborazione dati che rimuovono o codificano i dati personali. Quindi i dati diventano anonimi e non possono essere collegati a nessun individuo. L'anonimizzazione dei dati consente di rispettare i GDPR di tutto il mondo.

In questo meetup esploreremo i metodi e le tecniche di base per la codifica dei dati che statistici e data scientist utilizzano per rendere anonimi i dati con R.

Utilizzeremo il dataset prodotto dalle vostre risposte al seguente sondaggio ⬅️ compila il sondaggio e non mancare! 🙋‍♀️

COMPILA IL SONDAGGIO: https://forms.gle/TTwTECZqfW9Af5nz8

title: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup: Reproducible Computation at Scale in R with Targets  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup
description:
Following up our earlier meetup about drake, we have its creator talking about its successor, targets.

Thank you to EcoHealth Alliance for providing the Zoom link.

This meetup is the kickoff to the second 2020 R week with The R Conference for Government & Public Sector on December 2-4. Much like our recent NYR, this is virtual, so anyone around the world can attend. Visit https://rstats.ai/gov/ to learn more and use code nyhackr for a 20% discount on tickets, including workshops.

About the Talk:
Ambitious workflows in R, such as machine learning analyses, can be difficult to manage. A single round of computation can take several hours to complete, and routine updates to the code and data tend to invalidate hard-earned results. You can enhance the maintainability, hygiene, speed, scale, and reproducibility of such projects with the targets R package. targets resolves the dependency structure of your analysis pipeline, skips tasks that are already up to date, executes the rest with optional distributed computing, and manages data storage for you. It surpasses the permanent limitations of its predecessor, drake, and provides increased efficiency and a smoother user experience. This talk demonstrates how to create and maintain a Bayesian model validation project using targets-powered automation.

About Will:
Will is a statistician and software developer. He likes to solve scientific problems and engage with data analysis technologies.

The talk will begin at 7 PM EST and we will start admitting people to the event shortly before. Since this is completely remote there will be no pizza but everyone is encouraged to have pizza individually.

title: R-Ladies Chicago: InspiRing InstRuction: A panel on teaching #rstats for all audiences  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Someone in your department, company, or class comes to you and says: "I want to learn R; where do I start?" Or, "how do I take my R skills to the next level?"

Come hear from 3 R-Ladies on how to make R pedagogy work for different groups of people! :-)

R-Ladies Chicago and R-Ladies East Lansing will be a hosting a joint November virtual meetup featuring 3 panelists:

**Alison Hill** is a Data Scientist & Professional Educator at RStudio. Prior to joining RStudio, Dr. Hill was an Associate Professor and Center Assistant Director at Oregon Health & Science University in Portland, Oregon, where she was an NIH-funded Principal Investigator. Her work has been published in Pediatrics, Autism Research, and other peer-reviewed journals. She has developed and taught several advanced courses and workshops on data visualization and communicating with data. Dr. Hill is also an international keynote speaker, award-winning educator, and co-author of the book blogdown: Creating Websites with R Markdown.

**Marynia Kolak** is an Assistant Director of Health Informatics at the Center for Spatial Data Science at University of Chicago, where she also teaches full time as a Lecturer in Geographic Information Science. Dr. Kolak is interested in Social Determinants of Health (SDOH) and using open science tools as an exploratory data analytic approach to investigate issues of equity across space and time.

**Katie Fitzgerald** is a PhD Candidate in Statistics at Northwestern University. Her research is in statistical methods for social policy, including work in meta-analysis, data visualization, and statistical cognition. She is passionate about statistics education and pedagogy and is pursuing a career at a liberal arts university. When she's not doing statistics, you can find her at Northwestern’s gorgeous lakefront, biking, hammocking, reading, or indulging in good food.

Schedule for 11/12:

6:00-6:10 Meet and Greet!
6:10-6:25 Introduction from the panelists
6:25-6:50 Moderated panel
6:50-7:00 Questions from the audience

title: R-Ladies Vancouver: Tidying Up Messy Data: Hands-on Demos  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Hello R-Ladies

Are you an R beginner wanting to learn more about how to tidy up messy data? We covered in our this hands-on workshop!

Bruno Grande (he/him) has been training others in the ways of modern R programming since 2015. With a PhD in bioinformatics, he learned (the hard way) how to leverage the tidyverse toolbox to efficiently transform, analyze, and visualize data ranging from messy to tidy. As a Carpentries- and RStudio-certified trainer, he wishes to empower the next generation of researchers and professionals with the same data science skills that continue to bolster his career. He's currently promoting and implementing best practices in open science as a Bioinformatics Engineer at Sage Bionetworks in Seattle, WA.

Workshop details:
Day and time: Nov 18th, 2020 at 6pm
Webinar link: RSVP to view

******
About the workshop:

Do you have a messy dataset you'd like to have Bruno demo in this workshop? If so, we'd like to encourage you to submit your data here:
https://forms.gle/wdz4tDW3xaYfmZH28

Requirements and info for data submission:
- Preferably a data frame, but can be other data formats (e.g. Excel, JSON).
- Compliant with privacy requirements. ( ie No personal IDs, but redacted identifiers are okay)
- Contributors must feel comfortable having their dataset being tidied in front of the workshop audience (and possibly a broader audience on the Internet if the workshop gets recorded).
- Submissions can be anonymous
- Must be submitted by October 31st, 2020.

General workshop information:

-Please expect a hands-on session in a friendly and laid-back atmosphere where we all encouraged to learn together.
- All levels are welcome but be prepared that we created this with beginners in mind. You should be familiar with R and RStudio.
- Install R: https://mirror.its.sfu.ca/mirror/CRAN/
- Install RStudio (choose the Desktop version): https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/#download

1. Have your computer and a steady internet connection ready

See you there!

Lisa, Jasmine, Lucia, Zubia, and Yuka

title: R-Ladies Philly: Your first R package in 1 hour: Tools that make R package development easy  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Introduction

This workshop is for people looking to learn how to make their own R packages and learn how to use “usethis” and “devtools” for package development. The workshop will cover handy one time functions (i.e., use_this::create_package) as well as functions used continuously throughout package development (i.e., devtools::document). At the end of the hour you should have a working, well-documented package with a single function, as well as a better understanding of the files and file structure required for R packages.

This workshop is suitable for beginner to intermediate R users. Attendees should be familiar with functions, but will not be writing their own function in this workshop. Familiarity with pipe or tidyverse is helpful.

Speaker

Shannon Pileggi is an enthusiastic statistical collaborator and professional educator with over ten years of experience partnering on data analysis with diverse stakeholders in corporate settings, tech, public health, and clinical research. Shannon’s previous work experiences include supporting research on parasitic diseases at the CDC, developing a pilot college-wide intro stats course at the Institute for Quantitative Theory and Methods at Emory University, and instructing R/SAS programming, intro stats, and survival analysis courses at California Polytechnic State University, San Luis Obispo. Shannon is currently a Statistician at Adelphi Research in Doylestown, PA working in pharmaceutical market research. Shannon’s day-to-day in R include: fine-tuning ggplots to convey analysis results, contributing to an internal package to automate routine analyses/tasks, streamlining work-flows for repetitive analyses, and developing shiny apps.

description:

Every good chart started out as a bad one. In this workshop, we will discuss 1) basic visualization principles, and 2) resources, tools, tips, and tricks that help improve our charts and refine our data stories. Some familiarity with R and ggplot will be useful but not required - novice R users are encouraged to attend.

AGENDA:
TBD

ABOUT OUR SPEAKER:
Trang Le is a postdoctoral fellow with Jason Moore at the Computational Genetics Lab, University of Pennsylvania. She enjoys developing machine learning methods for rigorous analyses of biomedical data, including neuroimage, transcriptomic and genetic. She’s the author and maintainer of five R packages and active contributor of the automated machine learning tool TPOT. She holds a doctorate and a master’s degree in mathematics and two bachelor’s degrees in mathematics and geology. Reproducible research, inclusion and equity.

title: R-Ladies Riverside: Data Science as a Team Sport  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Hello RiveRside!

Join us for our next virtual meeting of learning and networking, Thursday, December 10th, at 5:00 PM (PST). We will hear from Gabriela de Queiroz, founder of R-Ladies and AI Inclusive. Gabriela will tell us about her career journey, as well as the many different roles a Data Scientist may have.

At the end of the meeting, there will be time to ask any questions you may have about data scientist careers or questions about R in general.

Don't forget to RSVP in our Meetup to get access to the meeting's ID and password.

Big thanks to UCR Library and UCR GradQuant for supporting us.

See you soon!

## Details

~ Data Science as a Team Sport ~

Data Science careers are in high demand, with many job opportunities and attractive salaries. As a relatively new career, it is ambiguously defined, and the job description of a data scientist can vary greatly from company to company. For those reasons, Data Science has attracted both new grads and career changers from all sorts of different fields. For Statisticians, Data Science is an exciting opportunity to apply your hard-earned skills to a variety of interesting and challenging problems. Having a solid Statistics background will give you a head start in that direction. However, Data Science is much more than pure Statistics knowledge. Being able to recognize and take advantage of a team with a diverse set of experiences will provide you with a unique opportunity to grow individually while benefiting your entire team. In this talk, I will walk you through my career journey, the different roles a Data Scientist can take, useful skills for a successful career, and lessons learned.

~ Bio ~
Gabriela de Queiroz is a Sr. Engineering & Data Science Manager at IBM where she manages and leads a team of developers working on Data & AI Open Source projects.
She works to democratize AI by building tools and launching new open source projects. She is passionate about making data science available to everybody and is actively involved with several organizations to foster an inclusive community.
She is the founder of AI Inclusive (ai-inclusive.org), a global organization that is helping increase the representation and participation of gender minorities in Artificial Intelligence. She is also the founder of R-Ladies (rladies.org), a worldwide organization for promoting diversity in the R community with more than 180 chapters in 50+ countries.
She has worked in several startups and where she built teams, developed statistical models, and employed a variety of techniques to derive insights and drive data-centric decisions.
She likes to mentor and shares her knowledge through mentorship programs, tutorials, and talks.

*Layla Bouzoubaa - Miami, FL*
Layla Bouzoubaa is a Lead Research Analyst for the University of Miami (UM) Miller School of Medicine's Department of Public Health Sciences (DPHS). She focuses on substance abuse research which targets interventions to patients suffering from opioid addiction - which includes developing web apps for resource mapping, data harmonization, and population statistics/visualizations to building models that will inform proper treatment. title: R-Ladies Miami: pmlbr and treeheatr: visualizing decision trees on benchmark datasets  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
The presentation of the decision tree with data represented as a heatmap is a new visualization that uncovers the tree's performance, the data's correlation structure, and the importance of each feature in predicting the outcome. Implemented in an easily installed package with a detailed vignette, treeheatr can be a useful teaching tool to enhance students’ understanding of a simple decision tree model before diving into more complex tree-based machine learning methods.

Trang is a postdoctoral fellow with Jason Moore at the Computational Genetics Lab, University of Pennsylvania. She enjoys developing machine learning methods for analyses of biomedical data, including neuroimage (functional/structural MRI), transcriptomics and genotypes. Most of the datasets she works with are high dimensional (i.e., have many predictors/features), so she spends most of her time building feature selection algorithms for these data. She trades her bias toward the nearest-neighbor concept for lower variance of her methods and better generalizability. When she is not knee deep in data, she runs, dance and seasonally skis.

title: R-Ladies Irvine: Regression Overview + A Study of Medical Treatments for COVID-19  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
# Schedule
Tuesday, November 17th, 6:30-8:30pm
6:30 - Zoom Breakout Rooms Networking Activity
6:55 - Announcements
7:00 - Regression Overview
7:35 - A Study of Medical Treatments for COVID-19
8:30 - Meeting Adjourned

# Regression Overview
Speaker: Madeline Bauer, PhD

Bio: Madeline Bauer holds a Ph.D. in Mathematical Statistics. She has collaborated with medical and surgical oncologists in the design and analysis of large-scale Phase III cancer clinical trials, using survival and Cox proportional hazards regression analysis. She has also worked closely with radiation biologists in developing and implementing innovative dose response designs for Phase I and II studies to evaluate dose escalation of radiation therapy, with immunologists developing designs for Phase II studies to evaluate combination therapy with biologic agents, and has used robust regression and data visualization tools in S-Plus and R to visualize dose response surfaces for combination antifungal drug therapy in murine models and in vitro drug susceptibility testing. Now retired, Dr. Madeline Bauer helps high school students with their science projects, mentors undergraduate statistics and data science students preparing for ASA DataFest, and serves as a co-organizer for R-Ladies Irvine.

Abstract: The general purpose of developing a regression model is to understand the association between a response Y and X and/or to predict Y given X, where X is a set of independent variables. In this talk, we give an overview of regression and highlight some of the regression packages available in R. We start with examples of suggested best workflow practices that are useful regardless of the specific regression model. For model-specific workflows, we take advantage of the "methods" associated with the model, such as "summary", "print", and especially "plot." These methods illustrate the individual package author’s approaches to check the model assumptions, estimate the association between the response and the covariates and evaluate the fit and accuracy of the resulting model. We will demonstrate these methods with real datasets. The data and R code will be available to download.

# A Study of Medical Treatments for COVID-19
Speaker: Song Zhai

Bio: Song Zhai is a Ph.D. candidate in the Department of Statistics at UC, Riverside. After finishing his master degree in the Department of Mathematics at Texas A&M University, Song Zhai joined UCR in Fall 2016, under the supervision of Dr. Xinping Cui. Song’s previous projects include a retrospective study for biomarker selection with Parkside Medical Group; efficient polygenic risk score developing at Merck; and best predictive biomarker identification with Xinping. Song’s research focus is on pharmacogenomics, with an emphasis on applications rooted in biomarker study, multiple testing, and causal inference.

Abstract: To the end of this study, various medical treatments for COVID-19 are attempted. A total of 417 patients were considered and 414 of them were included in this study (3 deaths) with mild-to-critical COVID-19. Patients were followed up for recurrence for 28 days quarantine after being discharged. We applied the Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE) to overcome the rare recurring events in certain patient subgroups. Virtual Twins Matching (VTM) analysis, facilitated by random forest regression, was performed for medical treatment-recurrence classification, while minimizing effects of confounding factors. We used the Multiple Comparisons with the Best (MCB) as the test of the best drug combination in each patient subgroup. The insights into combinatorial therapy found in this study shed light on the use of a combination of (biological and chemical) anti-virus therapy and/or anti-cytokine storm as a potentially effective therapeutic treatment for COVID-19.

# Meeting Materials
All meeting materials will be sent to registered attendees after the event.

title: R-Ladies Melbourne: How R you? - R-Ladies Melbourne 4th anniversary  [Virtual] , Australia, Australia
description:
Hi everyone!

To celebrate our 4th anniversary with the R-Ladies community we would like to re-propose an event format that we did in the past, which we named "How R you?"!

Have you ever had the thought: "I wonder how my friend is coding!" or "How would other people code this?" or "What's their favourite R tip?". Or maybe you have burning R questions but don't have R friends around you to help you debug it?
This is the time to share our coding thoughts, tips and questions that we could collectively answer!

We would like YOU TO SHARE WITH US YOUR FAVOURITE BITS OF R and/or a R RELATED QUESTION

WHAT TO DO

1. SHARE WITH US HERE https://forms.gle/qSt5Q8PRmCNp29Xe6 or via email to [masked], an R/R Studio function or functionality; a way to build a model or visualise your data that you use in your workflow or that you simply really like; your favourite R moment or tips from our events! You can also add something about yourself and in which field you use R. The format can be one slide, one R/Rmd script or anything that works for you!

To give you some ideas, this is the result from the last time we ran this event https://rladies-melbourne-tips.netlify.app/.

2. PRESENT IT at our event in 5 MINUTES. This will be a great opportunity to share your R tips, ask for feedback from the audience and practice your public speaking in a friendly, non-judgemental environment!

3. WE WILL CREATE ANOTHER R-LADIES MELBOURNE TIPS REPOSITORY. Submit something even if you think you might not be free on the night. We'd still love to combine all the R-Ladies tips in one Rmarkdown and make it available to everyone! Depending on the number of submissions we will restructure the repository into themes.

4. WIN A FABULOUS PRIZE! We will draft LUCKY WINNERS among the presenters to win an amazing prize (R EARRINGS, bags and much more!)!!

NETWORKING EVENT

Following the lightning talks, we will hold a networking event and online birthday celebration so that participants have the opportunity to interact with each other!

The format of the networking will be announced.

Even though some restrictions are being released this event will still be held online.

Looking forward to seeing you all,

R-Ladies Melbourne

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: Lightning Talks: This year I learned ... and it changed my life! R-edition  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
Let's be honest... 2020 has been a rollercoaster -- but surely some good has come out of it! In the R-Ladies Freiburg year-end Meetup, we'll focus on the positive things we've learned this year in R. And for this, we want to hear from you!

Whether it's a cool ggplot feature, a newly discovered package, a tip for using R-Studio, or an application of familiar tools to your own project, we know you have something interesting to share! In a 10-minute slot, you can present on anything you've learned this year in R, or walk us through a visualization / piece of code that you're proud of -- all in front of an easy, helpful audience who are there to cheer you on.

We're hoping to get a range of ladies* from different areas of interest, levels of expertise, and resident countries to join and share their tips with us! If you've never presented before, we want to specifically encourage you to try it out. So don't hesitate to sign up -- we look forward to hearing from you.

So bring a mug of Glühwein (mulled wine, or your beverage of choice) and celebrate a successful year of R with us in a festive, welcoming atmosphere -- see you there!

And, as a teaser, topics so far include:
- ...how to make sweet lollipop plots
-... small tricks to make big changes in your R-Studio experience
-... how to make presentations in R

Sign up for a talk here:
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1r3BNDPW0kkKSqd5LQNJjE8ezFblh2oOC1LcBXIxIBkc/edit

title: R-Ladies East Lansing: InspiRing InstRuction: A panel on teaching #rstats for all audiences w/ RLC  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Someone in your department, company, or class comes to you and says: "I want to learn R; where do I start?" Or, "how do I take my R skills to the next level?"

Come hear from 3 R-Ladies on how to make R pedagogy work for different groups of people! :-)

R-Ladies Chicago and R-Ladies East Lansing will be a hosting a joint November virtual meetup featuring 3 panelists:

**Alison Hill** is a Data Scientist & Professional Educator at RStudio. Prior to joining RStudio, Dr. Hill was an Associate Professor and Center Assistant Director at Oregon Health & Science University in Portland, Oregon, where she was an NIH-funded Principal Investigator. Her work has been published in Pediatrics, Autism Research, and other peer-reviewed journals. She has developed and taught several advanced courses and workshops on data visualization and communicating with data. Dr. Hill is also an international keynote speaker, award-winning educator, and co-author of the book blogdown: Creating Websites with R Markdown.

**Marynia Kolak** is an Assistant Director of Health Informatics at the Center for Spatial Data Science at University of Chicago, where she also teaches full time as a Lecturer in Geographic Information Science. Dr. Kolak is interested in Social Determinants of Health (SDOH) and using open science tools as an exploratory data analytic approach to investigate issues of equity across space and time.

**Katie Fitzgerald** is a PhD Candidate in Statistics at Northwestern University. Her research is in statistical methods for social policy, including work in meta-analysis, data visualization, and statistical cognition. She is passionate about statistics education and pedagogy and is pursuing a career at a liberal arts university. When she's not doing statistics, you can find her at Northwestern’s gorgeous lakefront, biking, hammocking, reading, or indulging in good food.

Agenda
===================
Times are in EST

7:00-7:10 Meet and Greet!

title: R-Ladies Amsterdam: [ONLINE] #IamRemarkable Workshop  [Virtual] , Netherlands, Europe
description:
Hi everyone,

We hope you are well during this time! While we as R-Ladies Amsterdam typically focus on developing hands- on skills- it's also important to learn how to vocalise your developed skills and achievements! As such, we are excited to invite you to attend the #IamRemarkable workshop as part of the #IamRemarkable Week running from 12-19 November. Join us to celebrate the power of diversity and allyship- and get inspired by remarkable stories and improve your confidence and self-promotion skills.

#IamRemarkable is a Google initiative empowering women and
underrepresented groups to speak openly about their
accomplishments in the workplace and beyond, thereby
breaking modesty norms and glass ceilings. Learn more at
g.co/IamRemarkable

In this interactive session, you will participate in group
discussions and exercises to develop the confidence and skills to
promote yourself effectively.

During the 90 min #IamRemarkable workshop we will:
- Share data and research regarding self promotion and
unconscious bias
- Go through the main exercise to help you articulate your
achievements and practice self promotion
- Have a discussion and share take home exercises
Feel free to sign up to discuss one of the chapters there!

ABOUT Janine
----------------------
Janine is a data scientist and one of the R-Ladies Amsterdam co-founders. Within the data science world she loves the intricacies that come with data science in the medical world, involving messy data (generation) and medical decision making that go beyond the technical nitty gritty. With her background in psychology she is well equipped to thoroughly understand the the requirements that go into a well designed data science project. She entered the world of data science through R- where her love for the language and the community developed. Now she is busy bringing the community in Amsterdam together supporting others in achieving their full programming potential through R.

REQUIREMENTS
----------------------
Just bring yourself! :)

LINK TO MEETUP
———————————
See on the right

CODE OF CONDUCT
----------------------------
We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct. Anyone who violates this community's Code of Conduct will be refused entry, expelled, and/or any other action deemed appropriate by the Organizer, regardless of event registration, Meetup membership or other condition. We are emphatically queer and trans-friendly. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. Please read the Code of Conduct here: https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct/

title: R-Ladies Johannesburg: Blogging with RMarkdown  [Virtual] , South Africa, Africa
description:
Are you an R user who would like to share more online? How about starting a new blog, with R Markdown (Rmd)?

Maëlle Salmon (https://masalmon.eu/), R(esearch) Software Engineer and a proud R-Lady, will be helping us get started!

In this 2-hour course with live coding, we'll go on two short adventures:

- setting up a scientific Rmd blog with the Distill framework, and the distill package

- setting up a scientific Rmd blog with the Hugo website generator and the hugodown package (also quickly presenting blogdown)

We'll prepare for the adventures by defining what we expect of an Rmd blog. We'll end the course by reflecting on each adventure as well as mentioning important future paths such as how to promote your blog. You should leave the course ready to start an R Markdown blog with your tool of choice, and knowing where to find more resources and help.

About the speaker:

Maëlle works remotely from Nancy, France, where she lives with her family.
She is a research software engineer with rOpenSci, besides other projects. In particular, currently, she works on the "HTTP testing in R" book thanks to funding from the R Consortium. She created the R-hub blog that features more or less niche topics about R package development, also thanks to funding by the R Consortium.
She also volunteers as an associate editor for rOpenSci's Software Peer Review (peer-review system of R packages), the main manager of R-Ladies Global Twitter account, and a member of the R Weekly team.

title: R-Ladies Washington D.C.: Books In Bars - Invisible Women  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Spend Friday night discussing Invisible Women (https://www.bookdepository.com/Invisible-Women-Caroline-Criado-Perez/9781784741723).

Winner of the 2019 Financial Times and McKinsey Business Book of the Year Award
Winner of the 2019 Royal Society Science Book Prize

Data is fundamental to the modern world. From economic development, to healthcare, to education and public policy, we rely on numbers to allocate resources and make crucial decisions. But because so much data fails to take into account gender, because it treats men as the default and women as atypical, bias and discrimination are baked into our systems. And women pay tremendous costs for this bias, in time, money, and often with their lives.

Celebrated feminist advocate Caroline Criado Perez investigates the shocking root cause of gender inequality and research in Invisible Women​, diving into women’s lives at home, the workplace, the public square, the doctor’s office, and more. Built on hundreds of studies in the US, the UK, and around the world, and written with energy, wit, and sparkling intelligence, this is a groundbreaking, unforgettable exposé that will change the way you look at the world.

PS Please contact the organizer if you need support finding the book.

title: Dublin R: Why R? Webinar:  Analysing Satellite Imagery with R  [Virtual] , Ireland, Europe
description:
- channel: youtube.com/c/WhyRFoundation
- date: every Thursday 7:00 pm (Irish Summer Time)
- format: one 45 minutes long stream + 10 minutes for Q&A
- comments: ask questions on YouTube live chat
- join Why R? Slack whyr.pl/slack/
- LinkedIn: www.linkedin.com/company/why-r
- Twitter: https://twitter.com/whyrconf/

Description:
Satellite imagery, such as freely available data from Sentinel-2 mission, enable us to monitor the Earth's surface frequently (every 5 days), and with a high spatial resolution (10-20 meters). Furthermore, Sentinel-2 sensors, including 13 spectral bands in the visible and infrared wavelengths, provide very valuable information which can be used to automatically perform tasks such as classify crop types, assess forest changes, or monitor build-up area development. This is particularly important now, in the era of rapid changes in the environment related to climate change. In R, there are plenty of tools and packages which can be used for satellite images such as pre-processing, analyzing, and visualizing data in a simple and efficient way. Also, the variety of methods, such as machine learning algorithms, are available in R and can be applied in the analysis of satellite imagery. I would like to show the framework for acquiring, pre-processing and preliminary analysis of the Sentinel-2 time series in R. It includes the spectral indices calculation, the use of the machine learning algorithms in the classification of land cover, and, the analysis of time series of imagery, i.e. determining the changes in environment based on the spectral trajectories of pixels.

Biography:
Ewa is a Ph.D. candidate in geography at the Jagiellonian University, and a research assistant at the Faculty of Forestry, the University of Agriculture in Kraków. In her research, she focus on the use of Sentinel-2 satellite imagery in determining different forest characteristics, such as tree species composition or detection of forest disturbances. She is also a big R enthusiast and she mostly use it in my analysis!

title: Seattle useR Group (R Programming Language): Spark and Pins; Scaling Data Science Across Storage  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
For this meetup Seattle UseR Group is teaming up with Javier Luraschi and Yitao Li from the RStudio mlverse team to talk about Spark and Pins. Since this talk will be hosted online, everyone in the world is welcomed, though it would be great if you registered on meetup.com! This will be an introductory talk from the creators of Spark and Pins.

Yitao Li, author and maintainer of the #sparklyr package, will present how to use Apache #Spark from R and new advancements in this space. We know we can easily use dplyr with Spark but, have you ever dreamed of using Spark with #tidyr? Well, this talk is for you!

Javier Luraschi, creator and maintainer of the #pins package, will present how to easily share your #datascience datasets in Amazon S3, Google Cloud, Azure, GitHub, Kaggle, and so on! All with the ease-of-use you expect from using R packages. Certainly, functionality Python and JavaScript users can't even dream of, or can they? Join us in this live stream to figure it all out!

title: Seattle useR Group (R Programming Language): Deep Learning with Torch; Scaling Data Science with GPU's  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
For this meetup Seattle UseR Group is teaming up with Sigrid Keydana and Daniel Falbel, from the RStudio mlverse team to talk about Deep Learning with Torch. Since this talk will be hosted online, everyone in the world is welcomed, though it would be great if you registered on meetup.com! This will be an introductory talk from the creators of torch and RStudio's AI blog.

Daniel Falbel, author and maintainer of the #torch package, will present how to use PyTorch from R and new advancements in this space. We know we can use TensorFlow to perform deep learning with R, but torch takes this a step further by providing similar functionality in a native R library using libtorch.

Sigrid Keydana, author of RStudio AI Blog and creator of the #tfprobability package, will complement this talk with an interview to Daniel to discuss broader topics in Deep Learning including transformational changes in our world that go beyond the technical aspects of this very new discipline.

title: Köln R User Group: November Virtual R Lightning Talks  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
The outline for the virtual meetup is as follows:

## Talk #1

Rachael Dempsey - Delivering Reproducible Insights with RStudio Connect

### About the talk

RStudio Connect is a publishing platform and computation engine for the work that teams create in R and Python. Connect provides a convenient place to share Shiny applications, R Markdown reports, dashboards, plots, models, APIs, Jupyter Notebooks, interactive Python content, and more. In this presentation, I will provide an overview of RStudio Connect and show how individuals are taking the work they have done on their own desktop and deploying that so anyone can interact with it, without having to know anything about R or Python themselves.

### About Rachael

Hi! I'm Rachael and I'm a Senior Enterprise Advocate at RStudio, helping data scientists from all over the world do more for their organization with RStudio's tools. I live in Boston and also organize the Boston useR Group, which are of course virtual now and open to anyone who is interested in attending. I love making people happy and learning from everyone I meet. In my role, I get to talk to awesome people every day and learn about what they're accomplishing with data. When I'm not working, I enjoy being active outside, doing yoga, running, playing guitar, trying new foods, and finding live music. I really like meeting new people and connecting others, so please say hello!

## Talk #2

Dirk Eddelbuettel - Using R via Rocker: A Brief Introduction with Examples

### About the talk
The Rocker Project (Docker Containers for the R Environment, https://www.rocker-project.org/), which is joint work with Carl Boettiger and Noam Ross, started in June of 2014 when Docker was still very new. The project has several hundred forks, over 1500 GitHub stars, and more than two million downloads on Docker Hub. This short talk will introduce the Rocker project, share a little of its history, and will demo use of a few applications of Rocker containers.

### About Dirk
Dirk Eddelbuettel (https://dirk.eddelbuettel.com) left U Karlsruhe in the fall of 1990 for France aiming for two quick terms ... and has yet to return. Following graduate studies in France he settled in Canada only to then move to the USA in 2000. He has contributed to the Debian and R projects since the mid- and late 1990s, and maintains and/or (co)-authors a number of packages in each. After more than two decades in quantitative finance, he now works on R integration for TileDB, a universal data engine, and teaches a Data Science Programming class at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.

## Social Gathering

After the talks we want you to virtually meet, chat, network, and discuss interesting topics.

description:

მარიამი მათემატიკოსი, ვალიდა კი ეკონომისტია. ისინი უძრავი ქონების და საბანკო სფეროებში მუშაობენ, სადაც, ყოველდღიურად აქვთ დიდ მონაცემთა ბაზებთან შეხება.

title: Taiwan R User Group / MLDM Monday: MLDM Monday @ 三創育成 | AI與法律：Automatic Law Report Generation, Taiwan, Asia
group: Taiwan R User Group / MLDM Monday
description:
本次聚會地點於三創育成基金會（11F）場地

講題：AI與法律：Automatic Law Report Generation

講題介紹：
路透社(Reuters)是世界三大媒體之一，然而其母公司湯森路透(Thomson Reuters)其實還有75%的業務投入在法律與財稅的資訊服務，旗下產品Westlaw是全球最大的法律資料庫，收錄了各式判例、法條、文章及見解。
龐雜的資料除了透過搜尋引擎進行結構化整理，還聘請了大量的法律專業人員來彙整報告，又稱Law Report。
Law Report讓使用者能快速的了解整起訴訟的關鍵訊息，更方便進行訴訟研究，極具附加價值。
然而彙整報告的人力費用不斐，在特定案例上也有時效性的要求。
Thomson Reuters Labs 近年導入深度學習，投入自動化生產Law Report的開發。
在本次演講，講者將分享入職八個月至今關於此主題的進展，並聚焦在Automatic Text Summarization。

講者介紹：
Leo Yang, Data Scientist @ Thomson Reuters Labs

(講者位於加拿大，本次分享，講者將用連線進行。)

title: Taiwan R User Group / MLDM Monday: MLDM Monday @ 三創育成 | A Model of Inductive Bias Learning, Taiwan, Asia
group: Taiwan R User Group / MLDM Monday
description:
本次聚會地點於三創育成基金會（11F）場地

講題：A Model of Inductive Bias Learning
講題介紹：

大部分的Deep Learning問題，都逃脫不了Multiclass Classification及Transfer Learning這兩種。例如，你訓練一個 MNIST Toy Example ，總共有十個類別，就是 Multiclass Classification 的問題。如果你用了 ImageNet Pre-trained Model，就是用了 Transfer Learning 。其實， Multiclass Classification 及 Transfer Learning 都屬於 Inductive Bias Learning。那什麼是 Inductive Bias Learning 呢？就是這些問題的 Inductive Bias ，也就是Low-level feature，不是人工先定義好的，而是從訓練中學習到的。

你也許會有這樣的疑問，為什麼一起訓練多個 Class 的分類，或是使用了 Transfer Learning，可以使每個類別所使用的 Training Data 減少？是因為這些 low-level feature 的共用，可以降低 Model Complexity ？本次主題主要是講解這篇 paper：A Model of Inductive Bias Learning [ https://arxiv.org/abs/1106.0245 ]。內容是定義了 Inductive Bias Learning 這個學習方式，以及它的的數學理論，以及它是如何降低 Model Complexity。不過由於這篇paper 是在 Deep Learning 盛行之前所發表的，它有許多內容是無法適用於現在的 Deep Learning，我也會補充另一篇將 Inductive Bias Learning 推廣到 Deep Learning 的 paper:
Meta-Learning_by_Adjusting_Priors_Based_on_Extended_PAC-Bayes_Theory [https://arxiv.org/abs/1711.01244] 。

講者介紹：Mark Chang

AI 工程師，也是 AI youtuber，直播主。主要興趣是推廣 Machine Learning 和 Deep Learning 的數學理論。相較於憑直覺或籠統的說法，使用嚴謹的數學理論，來解釋 Machine Learning 和 Deep Learning 遇到的各種情況，可以讓 AI 不再那麼黑箱，減少運算資源浪費及避免錯誤的決策。頻道：https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCckNPGDL21aznRhl3EijRQw?view_as=subscriber

Multi-objective optimization and applications

講題介紹：
隨著機器學習的演進，現在有很多強大的模型可以在很多應用中學的很好。但是往往在應用上，我們無法直接把這些模型直接使用。因為他們可能太大或是在某些地方特別容易犯錯。結果就是工程師們會花很多時間解決這些問題。在這個演講裡，我們討論如何把以上問題，以及其他現實問題寫成一個多目標最佳化的問題。然而，這些問題很難被快速解決。所以討論一些工具來有效率解決這些問題，包含強化學習，演化演算法等等。

講者介紹：
Henry 現在在Google Research當Tech Lead，做AutoML相關研究。

(講者位於美國，十二月將到香港一個月，本次分享，講者將用連線進行。)

title: R-Ladies Dallas: "Branching Out into Isolation Forests" with guest speaker Stephanie Kirmer  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
For the December edition of our R-Ladies Dallas webinar series, we are excited to welcome Stephanie Kirmer as our guest speaker. She will introduce the topic of Isolation Forests for tree-based anomaly detection.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Branching Out into Isolation Forests: Tree Based Anomaly Detection
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Abstract:
Isolation forests offer a new way to approach unsupervised anomaly detection problems, and in this talk attendees will get an end-to-end tutorial with code and visual explanations on how to apply the technique in R. Among other advantages, isolation forests offer interpretability and rapid runtime, so they are useful in business and production settings.

Bio:
Stephanie Kirmer is a Senior Data Scientist at Saturn Cloud, a platform enabling easy to use parallelization and scaling for Python with Dask. (But she still loves R as well.) Previously she worked as a DS Tech Lead at Journera, a travel data startup, and Senior Data Scientist at Uptake, where she developed predictive models for diagnosing and preventing mechanical failure. Before joining Uptake, she worked on data science for social policy research at the University of Chicago and taught sociology and health policy at DePaul University.

Slides/Code:
Stephanie's slides were prepared using the R xaringan package and are available in the following github repository in the 'r' subdirectory. Code used in her demo are also provided in the repo. You are invited to follow along during the presentation. https://github.com/skirmer/isolation_forests

Twitter: @data_stephanie

Website: http://www.stephaniekirmer.com/

*************************************************************************

You are encouraged to click the link below to keep up with the group project and to join the Slack community. Slack is a messaging platform where we will share open job opportunities, free or low-cost online training materials, and R-Ladies group projects that will help you practice your R programming skills and develop a portfolio that could be used to showcase your skills to hiring managers.

Webinar + Slack sign-up: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdJhvSg-YrNYOrmju1yrXvYhFM7xMey1WpDq1NSGIp6x41VaA/viewform

*************************************************************************

We expect all attendees to abide & be governed by our community code of conduct. Please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct.

title: R-Ladies Boston: CV Workshop  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada

title: R-Ladies Belo Horizonte: We R Ladies - Como criar um pacote do zero no R  [Virtual] , Brazil, Latin America
description:
Inscrições em: https://www.sympla.com.br/we-r-ladies---como-criar-um-pacote-do-zero-no-r__1043808

Para quem usa o software R frequentemente, a utilização de pacotes pode economizar tempo e ajudar a organizar projetos. Neste curso, iremos abordar todo o processo de criação de pacotes, assim como suas utilidades e aplicações. Para facilitar o desenvolvimento usaremos ferramentas disponíveis no RStudio Cloud.

Nível de Habilidade: Intermediário

Conheça a facilitadora:

Adriana dos Santos Lima - Cientista de Dados na Accenture (https://www.linkedin.com/in/adriana-lima-89a11b143/)
Carioca em Beagá. Adriana é graduada em Estatística pela UFF (Universidade Federal Fluminense) e Mestre em Estatística pela UFMG (Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais).
Cientista de dados nos dias úteis e espectadora fiel dos vídeos de decoração aos finais de semana. Trabalha atualmente na Accenture como Cientista de Dados onde atua em projetos que a permitem desenvolver desde o pré-processamento dos dados até a aplicação dos modelos de machine learning.
Apaixonadíssima pelo R, mas desenvolvendo uma leve paixonite pelo python nos últimos tempos. Acredita que programar é para TODOS e que o conhecimento em programação deve ser disseminado por aí. A sua paixão mesmo é estudar Estatística nas suas mais diversas áreas (a louca, né?) e recentemente decidiu se aventurar no mundo do Deep Learning.

FAQs:

O que é R?

R é uma linguagem de programação de computador e ambiente de software para computação estatística e gráficos. Confira aqui (https://www.r-project.org/). Ele é usado para análise e visualização de dados em uma ampla variedade de campos.

O que é R-Ladies?

A comunidade R-Ladies é uma organização global que promove a diversidade de gênero na comunidade da linguagem computacional estatística (R). Embora nossos eventos considerem pelo menos o interesse de nível básico em R (algum conhecimento anterior é útil, mas não obrigatório), você é mais que bem-vinde a participar de qualquer uma de nossas sessões para ver o que fazemos.

Onde posso acessar seus materiais?

Vamos carregar os materiais para a nossa pasta no GDrive (https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1UNO_46lSQ63aU71tIR70-7le0ez10HT5).

Eu conheço pouco ou nada sobre a linguagem R, ainda assim posso participar?

Absolutamente! Todos os níveis são bem-vindos, tudo o que você precisa é ter pelo menos algum interesse.

Preciso de alguma estrutura pra acompanhar o curso?

Para acompanhar o curso online, o ideal é ter acesso a um computador e internet rápida. Uma conta ativa no RStudio Cloud também será necessária. Veja como criá-la aqui: https://medium.com/rladiesbh/r-studio-cloud-como-programar-em-r-usando-a-web-aa6313a5fb8c

Vai ter certificado?

Vai sim, todo mundo que comparecer ao evento terá direito a um certificado de 6h.

O curso é gratuito?

Sim. Porém, teremos um número limitado de vagas gratuitas.

Eu sou homem, posso me inscrever?

Este grupo é principalmente voltado para o público feminino e LGBTQIA+, mas está aberto a todos que concordam com o CoC (https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct/). Dito isto, se você é um homem e quer participar dos nossos encontros, você está convidado a participar!

Projeto a ser ajudado em breve!

Ficou alguma dúvida?

É só enviar para [masked] ;)

title: R-Ladies Milan: Recommendation Engine from scratch!  [Virtual] , Italy, Europe
description:
Ciao di nuovo!
Siamo qui per un evento interessante:
Volete aggiornare il vostro skill set e imparare a costruire un sistema di raccomandazione da zero? Questo evento fa per voi!
Siamo lieti di ospitare un workshop virtuale con Avanade, leader mondiale nella fornitura di servizi digitali innovativi, cloud, business solutions ed experience desig.
In questo workshop imparerete:
* Costruzione di un Recommendation System tramite la libreria recommenderlab, allo scopo di suggerire delle “categorie letterarie” a utenti che comprano libri.
Il workshop sarà suddiviso in diversi step, dall’analisi del dataset alla costruzione di KPI, fino all’implementazione del modello di raccomandazione. Come ultimo step, per mostrare come usufruire del modello, mostreremo una ShinyApp che, prendendo in input alcune informazioni sui gusti dell’utente, restituisce le categorie suggerite

Level: Beginner
Il materiale per il workshop sarà condiviso prima dell'evento.

Speakers:
- Intro: Simona Radici, Talent Acquisition specialist e Giovanni Vetrella, Advanced Analytics Talent Community Lead.
- Hands on Lab: Michela Isella e Adriana Santacroce, Advanced Analytics Consultant e Advanced Analytics Analyst.

* Michela Isella, Laureata in Fisica, Data Scientist in Avanade. Parte del team di Advanced Analytics, specializzata nello sviluppo di soluzioni di Machine Learning tramite servizi del Cloud Microsoft Azure.
* Adriana Santacroce, ha un dottorato di ricerca nel campo statistico-demografico. Attualmente lavora nel team di Advanced Analytics di Avanade.

Ricordate che per questo workshop e' necessario aver installato R & Rstudio sul vostro pc. L'evento sarà in Italiano e sarà trasmesso in streaming tramite Zoom (Non è necessario installare zoom).
Il link per partecipare verrà condiviso dopo la registrazione.

- Introduzione: 17.30 - 17.45

Looking forward to meeting up with you all!

title: R-Ladies New York: Q&A with the Authors of "Data Science in Education Using R"  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
This event will be hosted over Zoom, and the link will be available on this Meetup page at noon on the day of the event. We will request your email address upon registration to ensure you receive the newly required Zoom passcode on the day of the event.

Agenda (subject to change):
7:30-7:35 pm: R-Ladies NYC Announcements
7:35-8:05: Book talk
8:05 - end Audience Q&A

---- Book description ----
Data Science in Education Using R is the go-to reference for learning data science in the education field. The book answers questions like: What does a data scientist in education do? How do I get started learning R, the popular open-source statistical programming language? And what does a data analysis project in education look like?

If you’re just getting started with R in an education job, this is the book you’ll want with you. This book gets you started with R by teaching the building blocks of programming that you’ll use many times in your career. The book takes a "learn by doing" approach and offers eight analysis walkthroughs that show you a data analysis from start to finish, complete with code for you to practice with. The book finishes with how to get involved in the data science community and how to integrate data science in your education job.

---- Speaker Bios ----
Ryan A. Estrellado (@RyanEs) has served public schools for over seventeen years as a school psychologist and administrator. Ryan writes about working with data, education, and other projects at https://ryanestrellado.com.

Emily A. Freer (@ebovee09) is the Director of Educational Development and Assessment at the Marquette University School of Dentistry. Learn more about Emily at https://emilyfreer.com.

Jesse Mostipak (@kierisi) is the Community Advocate for Kaggle, and has worked both as a high school science teacher and lead data scientist within education non-profits. To follow Jesse’s learning adventures in Python and deep learning, head over to https://jessemaegan.com.

Isabella C. Velásquez (@ivelasq3) is a data analyst committed to nonprofit work with the goal of reducing racial and socioeconomic inequities. To follow Isabella’s personal projects, join her at https://ivelasq.rbind.io.

title: R-Ladies Cuernavaca: Meetup Pruebas estadísticas en R: X2, t y ANOVA.  [Virtual] , Mexico, Latin America
description:
En esta sesión aprenderemos a realizar diferentes variantes de las pruebas estadísticas X2, t de Student y ANOVA con el lenguaje de programación R. Abordaremos cómo elegir un test estadístico, la interpretación de los resultados de las pruebas X2, t y ANOVA, así como otras pruebas y correcciones que se emplean en escenarios particulares.

NOTA ADICIONAL: Las alternativas no paramétricas a T de Student y ANOVA, así como los tests usados con grupos de muestras no independientes (ej. en los estudios longitudinales), se abordarán en sesiones posteriores.

TEMARIO

+ La Elección de una prueba estadística
+ Los supuestos de la prueba X2
+ Diferentes escenarios del uso de X2
+ Los supuestos de las pruebas T de Student y ANOVA
+ Diferentes escenarios del uso de T de Student
+ Diferentes escenarios del uso de ANOVA

CONOCIMIENTOS PREVIOS REQUERIDOS:

Este meetup está dirigido a personas con conocimientos básicos de R y de estadística. Contesta este cuestionario para saber si cuentas con los conocimientos necesarios para aprovechar esta reunión y qué recomendaciones u opciones tenemos para ti:

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScU4FKpJHPxAQ_bPyL0ptKnax3TcOlnOXwCDiPqV2lVbWYNyg/viewform

REQUERIMIENTOS DE SOFTWARE

+ R >=3.2 y RStudio
+ Paquetes de R: ggplot2, ggpubr, corrplot, MASS, tidyverse, corrplot

Puedes usar este comando para su instalación:
install.packages(c("ggplot2", "ggpubr", "corrplot", "MASS", "tidyverse", "corrplot"), dependencies = TRUE)

ACERCA DE LA PONENTE:

Aurora Labastida Martínez estudió la Licenciatura en Investigación Biomédica Básica y la Maestría en Ciencias Bioquímicas en la UNAM. Es especialista en análisis de datos de secuenciación masiva de ADN, un perfil que desarrolló gracias a la colaboración con expertas y expertos en ciencias biológicas y análisis de datos de la UNAM y, más tarde, de la iniciativa privada. Utiliza técnicas y trucos de R, Perl, Bash y AWK, además de técnicas variadas de estadística. Actualmente dirige el servicio de análisis de datos OMICs Analysis, en el que aplica sus conocimientos en proyectos de metagenómica y transcriptómica. Además se dedica a la panadería, la agricultura y a algunos proyectos mascota de programación.

CÓDIGO DE CONDUCTA
Recuerda leer y atender nuestro código de conducta disponible en https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct/

PATROCINADORES
Agradecemos a nuestros patrocinadores: R Consortium y Red Mexicana de Bioinformática

title: R-Ladies Medellín: Quinto Encuentro R-Ladies Medellín: ConfeMeet 2020  [Virtual] , Colombia, Latin America
description:
Para cerrar nuestros encuentros del 2020, queremos escuchar a los miembros de nuestra comunidad. Por esta razón, hemos organizado un ConfeMeet, un espacio en el que miembros de nuestra comunidad compartirán sus conocimientos y experiencia en el uso de R.

Les presentamos nuestros invitados para este ConfeMeet 2020:

Eddy Herrera Daza. Licenciado en Matemáticas Universidad Distrital. Magister en evaluación Universidad Santo Tomás y la Universidad Nacional de Colombia. PhD en Ingeniería Pontificia Universidad Javeriana. Actualmente es profesora de tiempo completo del Departamento de Matemáticas, Facultad de Ciencias, de la Universidad Javeriana y coordina las prácticas profesionales de estudiantes de matemáticas y de ciencias de datos de la Universidad Javeriana.

Andrés Eslava Daza. Economista y Estadístico de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia. Estudiante de Maestría en Ciencias- Estadística de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, sede Medellín. Actualmente trabaja en Corona Industrial como científico de datos y en la Oficina de Planeación de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia como desarrollador y consultor de aplicaciones Shiny.

Fundadoras de R-Ladies Barranquilla. R-Ladies Barranquilla es un capítulo local de la organización R-Ladies Global fundado este año en la ciudad de Barranquilla y que tiene como objetivo promover la diversidad de género dentro de la comunidad que maneja el lenguaje de programación R.

Nos sentimos muy felices y afortunadas de poder contar con estos invitados en nuestro primer ConfeMeet. El encuentro se llevará a cabo de forma virtual y puedes acceder desde el siguiente enlace:

https://udea.zoom.us/meeting/register/tJYpf-6orz0iGNd1Eg9SjWV-kjsd5sl2UvH2

Fecha: Miércoles 18 de noviembre
Hora: 6:30-8:30 p.m.

¡Anímate a participar!

Te esperamos
